name: Kedarnath

deity.mythology_form: Shiva hiding as a buffalo, only the hump surfaced here

location.sacred_geography: In the lap of the Garhwal Himalayas, between the Mandakini river sources and eternal glaciers. Behind the temple rises the 6940m peak Kedarnath. This is the highest of all 12 Jyotirlingas.

significance.char_dham_position: Northernmost of the four (Yamunotri, Gangotri, Kedarnath, Badrinath)
significance.panch_kedar_position: First and foremost of the 5 Kedar temples
significance.philosophy: Kedarnath represents Shiva as the hermit-god of the mountains—accessible only to those who make the difficult journey. The pilgrimage itself is the purification.

stats.stone_construction: Massive grey stone slabs, interlocking without mortar

description: Kedarnath is not just a temple—it's a test. At 11,755 feet, reached only by a freezing 16 km trek through Himalayan wilderness, this Jyotirlinga demands something from every pilgrim. Built by Adi Shankaracharya in the 8th century using massive interlocking stone slabs without mortar, the temple has survived 1200 years of earthquakes, avalanches, and the devastating 2013 floods that killed 6000 people—while a massive boulder stopped just behind the temple, diverting the floodwaters around it. Shiva tests you on the path. Then he protects you at the destination.
secret_hook: In 2013, a 16,000-year-old boulder 'appeared' behind the temple just in time to split the raging floodwaters, saving the structure while everything around was destroyed. Scientists can't explain how it got there...
